title: Potential flow
text:
In <a href="fluid%20dynamics">fluid dynamics</a>, potential flow describes the <a href="velocity%20field">velocity field</a> as the <a href="gradient">gradient</a> of a scalar function: the <a href="velocity%20potential">velocity potential</a>. As a result, a potential flow is characterized by an <a href="Conservative%20vector%20field%23Irrotational%20vector%20fields">irrotational velocity field</a>, which is a valid approximation for several applications. The irrotationality of a potential flow is due to the <a href="Curl%20%28mathematics%29">curl</a> of the gradient of a <a href="Scalar%20%28physics%29">scalar</a> always being equal to zero.
In the case of an <a href="incompressible%20flow">incompressible flow</a> the velocity potential satisfies <a href="Laplace%27s%20equation">Laplace's equation</a>, and <a href="potential%20theory">potential theory</a> is applicable. However, potential flows also have been used to describe <a href="compressible%20flow">compressible flow</a>s. The potential flow approach occurs in the modeling of both stationary as well as nonstationary flows.
Applications of potential flow are for instance: the outer flow field for <a href="airfoil">aerofoil</a>s, <a href="ocean%20surface%20wave">water waves</a>, <a href="electroosmotic%20flow">electroosmotic flow</a>, and <a href="groundwater%20flow%20equation">groundwater flow</a>. For flows (or parts thereof) with strong <a href="vorticity">vorticity</a> effects, the potential flow approximation is not applicable.
Characteristics and applications.
Description and characteristics.
In fluid dynamics, a potential flow is described by means of a velocity potential , being a <a href="Function%20%28mathematics%29">function</a> of space and time. The <a href="flow%20velocity">flow velocity</a> is a <a href="vector%20field">vector field</a> equal to the gradient, , of the velocity potential :
Sometimes, also the definition , with a minus sign, is used. But here we will use the definition above, without the minus sign. From <a href="vector%20calculus">vector calculus</a> it is known that the <a href="Vector%20calculus%20identities%23Curl%20of%20the%20gradient">curl of a gradient</a> is equal to zero:
and consequently the <a href="vorticity">vorticity</a>, the <a href="curl%20%28mathematics%29">curl</a> of the velocity field , is zero:
This implies that a potential flow is an <a href="irrotational%20flow">irrotational flow</a>. This has direct consequences for the applicability of potential flow. In flow regions where vorticity is known to be important, such as <a href="Wake%20%28physics%29">wake</a>s and <a href="boundary%20layer">boundary layer</a>s, potential flow theory is not able to provide reasonable predictions of the flow. Fortunately, there are often large regions of a flow where the assumption of irrotationality is valid which is why potential flow is used for various applications. For instance in: flow around <a href="aircraft">aircraft</a>, <a href="groundwater%20flow">groundwater flow</a>, <a href="acoustics">acoustics</a>, <a href="water%20wave">water wave</a>s, and <a href="electroosmotic%20flow">electroosmotic flow</a>.
Incompressible flow.
In case of an <a href="incompressible%20flow">incompressible flow</a> — for instance of a <a href="liquid">liquid</a>, or a <a href="gas">gas</a> at low <a href="Mach%20number">Mach number</a>s; but not for <a href="sound">sound</a> waves — the velocity has zero <a href="divergence">divergence</a>:

where is the <a href="Laplace%20operator">Laplace operator</a> (sometimes also written ). In this case the flow can be determined completely from its <a href="kinematics">kinematics</a>: the assumptions of irrotationality and zero divergence of flow. <a href="Dynamics%20%28physics%29">Dynamics</a> only have to be applied afterwards, if one is interested in computing pressures: for instance for flow around airfoils through the use of <a href="Bernoulli%27s%20principle">Bernoulli's principle</a>.
In two dimensions, potential flow reduces to a very simple system that is analyzed using <a href="complex%20analysis">complex analysis</a> (see below).

Small-amplitude sound waves can be approximated with the following potential-flow model:
which is a linear <a href="wave%20equation">wave equation</a> for the velocity potential . Again the oscillatory part of the velocity vector is related to the velocity potential by , while as before is the <a href="Laplace%20operator">Laplace operator</a>, and is the average speed of sound in the <a href="transmission%20medium">homogeneous medium</a>. Note that also the oscillatory parts of the <a href="pressure">pressure</a> and <a href="density">density</a> each individually satisfy the wave equation, in this approximation.
Applicability and limitations.
Potential flow does not include all the characteristics of flows that are encountered in the real world. Potential flow theory cannot be applied for viscous <a href="internal%20flow">internal flow</a>s, except for <a href="Hele-Shaw%20flow">flows between closely spaced plates</a>. <a href="Richard%20Feynman">Richard Feynman</a> considered potential flow to be so unphysical that the only fluid to obey the assumptions was "dry water" (quoting John von Neumann). Incompressible potential flow also makes a number of invalid predictions, such as <a href="d%27Alembert%27s%20paradox">d'Alembert's paradox</a>, which states that the drag on any object moving through an infinite fluid otherwise at rest is zero. More precisely, potential flow cannot account for the behaviour of flows that include a <a href="boundary%20layer">boundary layer</a>. Nevertheless, understanding potential flow is important in many branches of fluid mechanics. In particular, simple potential flows (called <a href="elementary%20flow">elementary flow</a>s) such as the <a href="free%20vortex">free vortex</a> and the <a href="wikt%3Apoint%20source">point source</a> possess ready analytical solutions. These solutions can be <a href="Superposition%20principle">superposed</a> to create more complex flows satisfying a variety of boundary conditions. These flows correspond closely to real-life flows over the whole of fluid mechanics; in addition, many valuable insights arise when considering the deviation (often slight) between an observed flow and the corresponding potential flow. Potential flow finds many applications in fields such as aircraft design. For instance, in <a href="computational%20fluid%20dynamics">computational fluid dynamics</a>, one technique is to couple a potential flow solution outside the <a href="boundary%20layer">boundary layer</a> to a solution of the <a href="Boundary%20layer%23Boundary%20layer%20equations">boundary layer equations</a> inside the boundary layer. The absence of boundary layer effects means that any streamline can be replaced by a solid boundary with no change in the flow field, a technique used in many aerodynamic design approaches. Another technique would be the use of <a href="Riabouchinsky%20solid">Riabouchinsky solid</a>s.
Analysis for two-dimensional flow.
Potential flow in two dimensions is simple to analyze using <a href="conformal%20mapping">conformal mapping</a>, by the use of <a href="transformation%20%28geometry%29">transformation</a>s of the <a href="complex%20plane">complex plane</a>. However, use of complex numbers is not required, as for example in the classical analysis of fluid flow past a cylinder. It is not possible to solve a potential flow using <a href="complex%20number">complex number</a>s in three dimensions.

Note that the fluid at the origin is at rest (this follows on differentiation of at ). The streamline is particularly interesting: it has two (or four) branches, following the coordinate axes, i.e. and . As no fluid flows across the -axis, it (the -axis) may be treated as a solid boundary. It is thus possible to ignore the flow in the lower half-plane where and to focus on the flow in the upper halfplane. With this interpretation, the flow is that of a vertically directed jet impinging on a horizontal flat plate.
